description.p: This function returns a Dirichlet process prior (DPP) distribution.

constructor-help-entry.usage: dnDPP( RealPos concentration, Distribution__<type> baseDistribution, Natural numElements )

argument.label: concentration
argument.description: The concentration parameter of the DPP (can be computed using fnDPPConcFromMean function).

argument.label: baseDistribution
argument.description: The DPP base distribution. This also gives the Rev type of the stochastic node created with this distribution.
argument.valueType: {Distribution__Real, Distribution__RealPos, Distribution__Natural, Distribution__Integer, Distribution__Probability, or Distribution__Simplex}

argument.label: numElements
argument.description: The number of elements distributed by the DPP.

constructor-help-entry.returnValue: Dist_dpp, Distribution__-see types above-[], Distribution, RevObject

details.p: This function constructs a Dirichlet process prior distribution. The DPP is used to model mixtures of data. For example, this distribution is used as a prior on lineage-specific substitution rates as a model for relaxing the assumption of a strict molecular clock (Heath et al. 2012).

In RevBayes this distribution is templated, meaning that it can be used for different types of parameters. Thus, depending on the type of the base distribution, the DPP can be a prior on elements with Real, RealPos, Integer, Natural, Probability, or Simplex parameters. The distribution constructor creates a stochastic node that is a vector of N elements of the type listed above, were N is the number of elements distributed under the DPP.

constructor-help-entry.example:
## number of DPP elements N <- 10
## prior mean number of categories k <- 8
## concentration parameter of the DPP a <- fnDPPConcFromMean(k, N)
## G_0 distribution G_0 = dnExponential(1.0)
## DPP distribution constructior rates ~ dnDPP(a, G_0, N)
